section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards, Alphabet Books (What Can You Find?, The Little Lion, My Mess)

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon? and we talked about the letters Ff, Ll and Mm.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review the Alphabet Cards Use the Alphabet Cards for letters Ff, Ll, and Mm. Name and show each uppercase and lowercase letter. This is the letter Ff. The letter Ff makes the /f/ sound you hear at the beginning of the word fox. Repeat for the other letters.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today you will share Alphabet Books with your partners. After you share the books with your partners, we’ll all share them together.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Point out the letters on the cover of the book. Model saying the letters—for example Ff, and making the sound /f/—and then looking for the picture that shows a word that begins with the sound, fox.

Assign partners. Help them isolate the sound and look for pictures that begin with that sound. What letters are on the cover of the book you chose? What sound does that letter make? What word do you see on this page that begins with that letter and sound?
Do the Activity Have partners go through the books and show each other pictures for the target sound.
Share Invite partners to share their books with the group.
Practice Letters Have children practice writing the letters Ff, Ll, and Mm. Next to each letter, ask children to draw a picture of something they remember that begins with that sound.
Do a picture walk through the book before children work in pairs. Help children point to and name each picture that begins with the sound, before they work with their partners.
Invite children to use the pictures and tell the story of what is happening on each page.

Multilingual learners may need extra time to review the letter name and sound before they begin. You might also want to do a picture walk through the book before they work with partners. Name the picture that begins with the sound and have them repeat it.
To help a child who needs support to focus, pair that child with another child who is more focused. Also give that child a Magnetic Letter to use to match the letter in the book.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Prepare ahead a paper Stegosaurus puppet; half paper plates, paper triangles, scraps, scissors, glue, crayons, markers

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we reread the story How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon? We read about big dinosaurs and saw how they moved through their homes and at the doctor’s offices.
We practiced moving carefully in space when we moved through an obstacle course.
In our activity today, we will make Stegosaurus dinosaurs and use them to remind us about moving carefully when we are near each other.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Show children a completed Stegosaurus puppet. Point out the things they can use to make their dinosaurs. Give children time to complete their dinosaurs.

Ask Invite children to use their completed puppets to answer each question, responding with what “Dino Says.” What should we say when we need someone to move out of our way? What should we say if we accidentally bump into someone else? What should we do with our hands in Circle Time? With our feet?

Talk About the Activity Have children talk about why it is important to move carefully around other people and other things. How do you feel when someone moves carefully around you and respects your personal space?
If children need support responding to the questions, provide dialogue prompts such as “Excuse me. Can you pl move?” or “Ex me.” Review common polite phrases such as please, excuse me, and thank you.

Invite children to create a skit about their dinosaurs. Encourage children to think of situations such as a crowded room, a busy park, or a packed playground. Invite children to think of appropriate responses such as taking turns or staying in their own personal space.

Invite multilingual learners to act out each scene using gestures and facial expressions to show their feelings. Name the emotion the child is expressing, and draw a face showing that emotion and label it.

For those children who may need additional support making their Stegosaurus puppets, provide pre-made shapes or invite children to create their own original dinosaur puppets. Place more emphasis on the role-playing portion of the activity and less emphasis on making the puppets.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we reread the story How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon? Now we are going to think about rhyming words. When we reread the story, we noticed different sets of rhyming words. These words made the story fun to read and listen to!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Rhyming Words Remember that words that rhyme end with the same sound.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In our activity today, we will make get-well cards for a sick dinosaur. In our cards, we will use a pair of rhyming words, either from the story or that we think of on our own.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Provide each child with a piece of paper, folded in half like a card, and plenty of crayons and markers.

Ask Children to draw a picture on the front cover of the card. Then ask them to write or tell you a pair of rhyming words for the inside of the card—either from the book or that they think of on their own. For example, nose/rose; flu/atchoo; whine/mine.
Repeat When children have completed their cards, have them read or say their rhyming words aloud.
Talk About and Practice Rhyming Have children tell how they know when words rhyme. Have them turn to a partner to think of other pairs of rhyming words. Words can be nonsense words.

Turn to the first page of the story with a pair of rhyming words and read the words, emphasizing the two words that rhyme. Tell children the first word of the rhyming pair, then reread the words and have them identify the second word of the rhyming pair.
Challenge children to think about other words that might fit the story and rhyme.

For multilingual learners, give an example of rhyming and non-rhyming words from the story. Then, continue with repetition of the examples throughout the story. Help them understand that it is the sound at the end of the words—not the letter—that rhymes.

For those children who have difficulty hearing rhyming patterns, present two words from the story on chart paper or a whiteboard. Ask them to listen as you read the pair of words and move a finger underneath the letters in the words. Have the children give other words that rhyme. These can be nonsense words.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials soap, paper towels

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the Big Chart of Big Ideas: Keep Your Hands Clean, and we learned a song about washing our hands.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Use the Vocabulary Cards to review the words scrub and rinse.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today, we will talk about the times in our day when we wash our hands. Then we will look at our Big Chart and follow the directions to wash our hands. Finally, we will say the steps for washing our hands in order.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Invite children to name specific scenarios where washing hands is necessary. Once a child names an example, hand the child a paper towel “ticket.” Provide support by asking questions that will help children name scenarios on their own. Once every child has a paper towel “ticket,” review the Big Chart and the steps for washing hands. Children will then wash their hands, one at a time, while singing “The Alphabet Song.”
Repeat Continue to review each of the steps for washing hands.
Sharing the Steps Together, have children say the steps for washing hands, saying the number of each step before describing it.

Keep the Big Chart where children can easily see it. As they wash their hands, talk them through each step. Say the number of each step so they remember that there are five. Remind them to sing the “The Alphabet Song” aloud or to themselves as they wash.
Invite children to draw a picture for each step of the handwashing process. Have them add a word or two that will help them remember the step. Have them mix up the cards and put them back in order.

For multilingual learners, repeat the steps for handwashing multiple times. Then have the children act out each step with you and talk about each one. Above the classroom sink, display a poster with each of the steps for handwashing, using numbers to indicate the steps.

For children who may struggle with holding a bar of soap and scrubbing their hands, provide liquid soap. Remind children to think about this week’s Mind Builder and respecting each other’s personal boundaries by getting soap and water only on themselves.
